metadata.title: Syntheses of four novel silicate-based nanomaterials from coal gangue for the capture of CO2

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Fuel

Full Length Article
Syntheses of four novel silicate-based nanomaterials from coal gangue for the capture of CO2 Yu Wua,b, Hong Dua,b, Yajun Gaoa,b, Xiaoyao Liua,b, Tingyu Yanga,b, Long Zhaoa,b, Xiaoqing Yuea,b, Shuai Zhanga,b, Jianbin Zhanga,b,⁎
a College of Chemical Engineering, Inner Mongolia University of Technology, Hohhot 010051, China b Inner Mongolia Engineering Research Center for CO2 Capture and Utilization, Hohhot 010051, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Coal gangue Silicate-based nanomaterials CO2 adsorption Thermodynamic parameters
A B S T R A C T
As one of the most important approaches to reduce CO2 emission from various combustion processes, CO2 adsorption capture is facing several many challenges, including high adsorbent cost, high energy cost, and low CO2 selectivity. In this work, four novel silicate-based nanomaterials (SBNMs), including magnesium silicate (MgSiO3), manganese silicate (MnSiO3), copper silicate (CuSiO3) and zirconium silicate (ZrSiO4), were fabricated via hydrothermal method with SiO32− extracted from coal gangue (CG) for the adsorption capture of CO2. Under the optimum conditions, the SiO32− extraction ratio from the CG reached to 77.69%. The extracted SiO32− was used to synthesize SBNMs with high surface area and high thermal stability, which were characterized with Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction, transmission electron microscopy, and nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms technologies. These as-obtained SBNMs exhibited CO2 adsorption capability of (7.82–17.93) cm3/g at 25 °C under 1 atm, respectively. The CO2 adsorption data were successfully fitted with Freundlich model, and the adsorption processes were obvious chemically favored, spontaneous and exothermic according to thermodynamic parameters, including Qst, ΔGads, ΔHads and ΔSads. Significantly, all SBNMs showed a excellent cycle performance and strong selectivity toward CO2 over N2. The aim of this work is to provide a new method of utilization of coal gangue waste and a low-cost, and highly selective CO2 adsorbents.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
CO2, as a main greenhouse gas, it contributes to global warming significantly. Therefore, CO2 emission control have been extensively studied, and one of the most important approaches is CO2 capture, including adsorption, absorption, and membrane separation [1]. Among these technologies, the adsorption in porous materials has better application prospects due to its wide application conditions, low cost, low energy consumption and low corrosion [2–5]. Currently, commonly used solid adsorbents include zeolites [6–8], porous carbon [9], MOFs [10], porous polymers [11], and silicates materials [12–14]. Recently, metal-based silicates materials have attracted significant prospect owing to its relatively high theoretical adsorption capacity and good thermal stability [15]. For example, Ren et al. [16] synthesized aminegrafted mesoporous copper silicates to capture CO2; Duan et al. [17] prepared lithium silicate to adsorb CO2 at high temperature; Hitch et al. [18,19] used mineral carbonation technology to react CO2 with magnesium silicate or calcium silicate to reduce CO2 emissions. However, most silicates adsorbed CO2 by chemical adsorption, while only a few
silicate materials physically adsorbed CO2. Silicate materials have high surface areas and a rich pore structure, which is an advantage of physical adsorption [16]. Therefore, we synthesized mesoporous silicates to explore their physical adsorption process with CO2, and the raw materials came from a large number of waste coal gangue discharged from the coal mining process, which not only realized the green application of waste, but also reduced the emission of CO2.
Coal consumption accounted for over 70% of primary energy consumption in China [20], in which a large amount of coal gangue (CG, 10–15% of annual coal) was produced as a solid waste. According to the statistics in 2010 [21], the amount of produced CG was up to 450 Mt, and it was predicted to run up to more than 700 Mt in 2020 in China. Except that CG occupied a great number of land resources, it was very hazardous to the surrounding environment due to the included toxic heavy metal and other pollutants, including sulfur, arsenic, mercury and fluorine, to water system and air [22–24]. Therefore, it is very important to utilize CG wisely. Up to present, the CG has been mainly used in power generation [25,26], building material [27,28] and pavement [29], although these applications could not fully utilize the

potential of CG. Since the chemical components of CG mainly included silicon (30–60%) and aluminum [21], we had synthesized a SiO2 material [30] and a porous silicate material [31] from CG with 40.24% of SiO32− previously, and their adsorption amounts of CO2 reached to 4.93 cm3/g and 18.82 cm3/g, respectively. To the best of our knowledge, silicates prepare from CG, including MgSiO3, MnSiO3, CuSiO3, and ZrSiO4, to explore the physical adsorption processes of CO2 was rarely reported, and this work is still a challenge.
In this study, four novel SBNMs, including MgSiO3, MnSiO3, CuSiO3 and ZrSiO4, from CG with thermal treatment, were synthesized to adsorb CO2 for the first time. After NaOH solution was used to extract SiO32− from CG, SiO32− reacted with N (N = MgCl2·6H2O, MnCl2·4H2O, CuCl2, and ZrCl4) to generate SBNMs with high thermal stability, high surface areas, and high selectivity to CO2 over N2. And all SBNMs showed acceptable CO2 adsorption capability under ambient pressure, which provided a great potential of CG in the capture of CO2 with low cost, low energy cost, high cycle property and strong CO2 selectivity.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
The CG was supplied by Ordos Dongsheng Lijiahao coal mine from Inner Mongolia province (China). NaOH and HCl were purchased from Yongsheng Fine Chemical Co (Tianjin, China), and MnCl2·4H2O and MgCl2·6H2O were purchased from Sailboat Chemical Reagent
Technology Co (Tianjin, China). CuCl2 was purchased from Macklin Industry Inc, and ZrCl4 was purchased from Aladdin Industry Inc. All chemical agents were analytical grade and used directly.

sections.heading: 2.2. Extraction of SiO32− from CG
sections.text:
The CG was grinded with a ball mill, sieved through 200 mesh net, and then calcined at 600–1100 °C [30]. Because the activity of coal gangue waste is low, and in terms of current technical conditions, calcination is an effective means to stimulate the activity of coal gangue [31]. In the calcination process, the silicon oxide tetrahedron and the aluminum oxide surface structure are destroyed, so that the calcined coal gangue contains a large amount of active silica and alumina to be extracted. Then, the calcined coal gangue (CCG) was mixed with NaOH solution at a certain temperature. After the reaction, the mixture was filtrated under vacuum and the filtrate was used as a silicon liquid (SL) with SiO32−, and the reaction mechanism was shown as follows:
Al2O3∙2SiO2·2H2O → Al2O3∙2SiO2 + 2H2O (600 °C) (1)
Al2O3∙2SiO2 → γ-Al2O3 + 2SiO2 (600–1000 °C) (2)
SiO2 + 2OH− → SiO32− + H2O (600–1000 °C) (3)

sections.heading: 2.3. Preparation of SBNMs
sections.text:
The procedure used for the preparation of SBNMs with SL and N was as follows: 0.1 M of N solution (100 mL) was mixed with 0.1 M of SL (100 mL), and about 10 M of HCl was added to the N-SL mixture to make pH = 10.00. Afterwards, mixture was hydrothermally treated at 140 °C for 2 h, Then, the products were vacuum filtration and washed with deionized water several times. Finally, the solids were obtained and dried at 120 °C for 2 h. The reaction processes were shown as follows, and the schematic preparation procedure was presented in Fig. S1.
SiO32− + Mg2+ → MgSiO3↓ (4)
SiO32− + Mn2+ → MnSiO3↓ (5)
SiO32− + Cu2+ → CuSiO3↓ ( 6)
SiO32− + Zr4+ + 2OH− → ZrSiO4↓ + H2O (7)

sections.heading: 2.4. Characterization
sections.text: The chemical composition of CG was measured by X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectrometer (Rigaku ZSX Primus II). The crystalline structure of CG, CCG and SBNMs were checked by X-ray diffraction (XRD) (Shimadzu, D/max-2200/PC) with Cu Kα radiation at 40 kV and 40 mA. FTIR spectra of CG, CCG and SBNMs were measured on the KBr pellet technique (Nicolet, Nexus 670). The surface of chemical composition and atomic valence of the materials were represented by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) on a KRATOS Axis Ultra X-ray photoelectron spectrometer. The morphology of CG, CCG and SBNMs were obtained by scanning electron microscope (SEM, S-3400N, Japan) and transmission election microscopy (HR-TEM, JEM-2100, Japan). N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of SBNMs were performed by a 3H2000PS2 analyzer. The thermal stability of SBNMs were acquired by thermogravimetry and differential thermogravimetry (TG-DTG) analysis (Q50TGA, America). Dry N2 was used as a stripping gas. The heating rate was 10 °C/min, and the samples were heated from room temperature to 1000 °C.

sections.heading: 2.5. CO2 adsorption
sections.text: The adsorption of ultrahigh purity gaseous CO2 (99.999%) and N2 (99.999%) on the synthesized SBNMs were measured at 25 °C and 1 atm with the 3H-2000PS2 analyzer, in which approximately 600–1000 mg of each sample was loaded in a round bottom glass tube.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of CG
sections.text:
The primary chemical composition of CG was determined with XRF as shown in Table 1. According to the content of SiO2 and Al2O3 in Table 1, it indicated that CG was clay rock. And the color of raw CG was light brown. After high temperature roasting of 600–1100 °C, the CG turned to brick red.
Fig. 1(a) showed the XRD patterns of CG and CCG at different calcination temperatures. As illustrated in Fig. 1(a), the main mineral compositions of CG were quartz, kaolinite, gismondine and albite [32]. The characteristic peak of kaolinite (d= 0.7208 nm) [33] disappeared at 600 °C, due to the removal of OH− at a high temperature, the destroy of (0 0 1) [33] crystal face structure of kaolinite, and the transformation of kaolinite into amorphous metakaolinite [34]. At 1000 °C, the strength of diffraction peak (2θ= 20.98°) [35] was decreased, indicating that the quartz structure was damaged and metakaolinite was decomposed into active silica and alumina. Additionally, the mullite diffraction peaks appeared at the calcination temperature of 1100 °C [27]. Therefore, Si element could be extracted from the CCG at 600–1100 °C.
As shown in Fig. 1(b), the characteristic FTIR peaks of CG at 3696 cm−1 and 3620 cm−1 were due to the inner and outer OH−
stretching vibrations [36], which were mainly regarded as the OH group of kaolinite. The band at 533 cm−1 in the CG was indicative of the presence of kaolinite [37]. Whereas, the bands of kaolinite were not found in the CCG at 600–1100 °C, which indicated that Kaolinite lost its crystallization water to form metakaolinite, and metakaolinite continued to decompose to form amorphous SiO2 and γ-Al2O3 [34]. The peak at 908 cm−1 was due to the vibration of the Al-OH bond [28], and the characteristic peaks at 695 and 750 cm−1 were due to the bending vibration of Si-O-Si [31]. The characteristic peak at 1430 cm−1 belonged to anti-symmetric stretching of CO32− [38], which indicated the existence of carbonate in the CG. The peaks at 3424 cm−1 and 1628 cm−1 were due to the O–H stretching and bending modes of molecular water [34]. The Si-O-Si stretching vibrational frequencies at 1032, 1009 and 1102 cm−1 in CG were combined into a broad peak at 1048 cm−1 at 600–1100 °C, indicating the formation of active silica [39,40].
According to FTIR and XRD results, the tetrahedron structure of silicon in the CG was destroyed after 600 °C, and a large amount of active silica was formed, which was the basis for the formation of SL in the next step.
In order to gain further insight into the morphological change, SEM investigation was conducted on the CG and the CCG from the calcination at 1000 °C (Fig. 1c and d). The structure of CG was compacted and agglomerated together in Fig. 1(c). In contrast, Fig. 1(d) showed that the structure of CCG after the calcination at 1000 °C was very loose. At a high calcination temperature, the structure of CG was expanded and showed an amorphous structure with more micropores, multiple bonds, multiple phases (eg. SiO2 and A12O3) and higher internal energy [41].

sections.heading: 3.2. Extracting of SiO32− from CCG
sections.text: The specific conditions for extracting of SiO32− from CCG were shown in the SI. Based on the above results, it was practical to use the CCG to extract SiO32− with 77.69% yield and then to produce SBNMs under the optimum conditions: calcination temperature of 1000 °C, the NaOH concentration of 150 g/L, the m(coal gague)/m(NaOH) ratio of 15, the reaction temperature of 100 °C, and the reaction time of 2 h.

sections.heading: 3.3. Effects of four factors on syntheses of SBNMs
3.3.1. Single factor experimental design
sections.text:
To determine the adsorption capacity of CO2 on MnSiO3 at 25 °C, the four parameters, including pH, molar ratio of SiO32− to MnCl2 (m (SiO32−)/m(Mn2+)), temperature, and time, were systemically investigated.
As shown in Fig. 2(a), the maximum CO2 adsorption amount of MnSiO3 towards CO2 was 12.77 cm3/g under pH = 10.00 at 25 °C. The CO2 adsorption amount of CO2 was simultaneously increased with the increase of pH from 6.00 to 10.00. The CO2 adsorption amounts of both samples at pH = 11.00 and pH = 12.00 solutions were less than 12.77 cm3/g. Both BET surface areas of both samples at pH = 11.00 and
pH = 12.00 solutions were 391.91 m2/g and 198.38 m2/g (Table 2). However, the BET surface area of sample from pH = 10.00 solution was 460.05 m2/g. These results indicated that pH affected both the formation of product’s pore structure and its adsorption amount of CO2. As shown in Fig. 2(b), the CO2 adsorption amount was increased with the increase of m(SiO32−)/m(Mn2+) ratio from 1: 0.2 to 1: 3. And the maximum capacity of 12.77 cm3/g with MnSiO3 at m(SiO32−)/m (Mn2+) = 1: 1. Meanwhile, from Table 2, we could also see that with the increase of Mn concentration, the specific surface area increased first and then decreased. When the molar ratio was 1: 1, the maximum
value was 460.0 m2/g, and the adsorption capacity of CO2 was the highest. This may be due to the larger specific surface area which provided more channels, thus increasing the CO2 adsorption capacity. As shown in Fig. 2(c), with the increase of temperature, the CO2 adsorption amount was increased first and then decreased, and this was consistent with the trend of the specific surface area data in Table 2. Because the serious agglomeration of sample at high temperature, the increase of temperature caused the decrease of the specific surface area and then affected the adsorption amount of CO2. From Fig. 2 (d), we could see that there was no corresponding relationship between the
specific surface area and the CO2 adsorption capacity at different time, it may be related to the size of the pore diameter. At 10 h, the pore diameter was smaller, although at 8 h, the pore diameter was smaller than that at 10 h, but at 8 h, the specific surface area was only 88.3 m2/ g, and the number of pores was smaller, which will affect the adsorption capacity of CO2. So, the optimum reaction time was 10 h. Therefore, the optimum temperature and time were set at 140 °C and 10 h. Meantime, the CO2 adsorption amount was 17.93 cm3/g.
All of these results showed the optimum reaction conditions for the adsorption of CO2 on the materials were pH = 10.00, m(SiO32−)/m (Mn2+) = 1: 1, 140 °C, and 10 h.

The code of 3 factors and 3 levels was shown in Table 3, and the design of Box-Behnken experiment [43–45] and the CO2 adsorption amount were shown in Table 4.

sections.heading: 3.4. Characterization of SBNMs
sections.text:
FTIR spectra of four SBNMs were carried out to determine their surface functional groups (Fig. 4). The spectra of samples (a, b, c and d) had four peaks. The peaks at 3429 and 1632 cm−1 were characteristic to the stretching and bending modes of adsorbed H2O in the samples. The other peaks at 996 and 647 cm−1 were ascribed to the Si-O vibration in SiO32−, which confirmed the successful formation of four SBNMs [46–48].
XRD patterns of these four SBNMs were shown in Fig. S4. The peaks
of 2θ= 20, 60 and 72° [49,50] were the diffraction patterns of MgSiO3, which had low crystallinity with a large number of amorphous pores (Fig. S4(a)). Fig. S4(b) showed the XRD patterns of MnSiO3 was in amorphous state with a relatively strong diffraction peak at 2θ= 33° [47]. The low diffraction peaks at around 2θ= 20, 31, 57 and 63° [16] confirmed the absence of crystalline phases and confirmed the amorphicity of CuSiO3 in Fig. S4(c). Fig. S4(d) represented the formation of ZrSiO4 due to the presence of a broad peak around at 2θ= 28° [48].
XPS spectra (Fig. 5) were also used to determine oxidation states of the samples on their surface. It could be clearly seen that the spectrum contains Mg (13.76%), O (51.16%), Si (15.42%), Na (3.47%) and C (16.2%) in Fig. 5(a). The binding energy of Na1s was shown at 1079 eV in all samples, indicating that the existence of Na+ in all samples that came from the silica extraction with NaOH. Three O1s peaks at around 531.6, 532.0 and 533.5 eV as shown in Fig. 5(b). The peak at 531.6 eV belonged to O1s in Mg(OH)2. The peak at 532.0 eV was attributed to O1s in Si-O-Si band, and the peak at 533.5 eV corresponded to O1s in Si-O-Mg band that confirmed the existence of MgSiO3. The peak at 1304.1 eV was attributed to Mg1s in Si-O-Mg bond as shown in Fig. 5(c), and the other peak at 1305.1 eV corresponded to Mg1s in Mg (OH)2. As shown in Fig. 5(d) with the two typical peaks of Si2p, the peak at 102.8 eV was attributed to Si2p in Si-O-Si bond, while another peak at 103.9 eV was assigned to Si2p in Si-O-Mg band [50]. These results further confirmed that MgSiO3 was synthesized successfully as well as MnSiO3, CuSiO3 and ZrSiO4 (Fig. S4 and 7).
Fig. 6(a)–(d) are N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms at 77 K and the corresponding BJH (Barrett-Joyner-Halenda) pore-size distribution of MgSiO3, MnSiO3, CuSiO3, and ZrSiO4. As shown in Fig. 6(a)–(d), these isotherms were type-IV adsorption/desorption isotherms with hysteresis loops of mesoporous materials, as defined by International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) [51,52]. The hysteresis
loops of isotherm in Fig. 6(a) and (b) belonged to H4 type, and the capillary condensation were shown at p/p0 = (0.4 and 0.9), which probably showed narrow slit-like pores [53]. However, isotherms in Fig. 6(c) featured as H2 hysteresis loop at p/p0 = (0.4–0.8), and the sharp capillary condensation suggested the mesoporous structure with cage-like pores [53]. The IV-type isotherm in Fig. 6(d) with an H3 hysteresis loop and a very sharp tail at p/p0 > 0.8 indicated the existence of larger pores with a wide pore size distribution than samples (a), (b) and (c). And the pore-size of synthesized MgSiO3, MnSiO3, CuSiO3 and ZrSiO4 all exhibited very sharp distribution centered at 3.63 nm, 2.02 nm, 3.61 nm and 13.14 nm, which showed that the materials belonged to mesoporous structure. And the volumes of pore and
pore sizes of these materials were also listed in Table 6. From the above analysis, it could be seen that the specific surface area of zirconium silicate was the smallest among the four kinds of silicates, and the adsorption amount of CO2 was the least, indicating that the specific surface area had a certain influence on the adsorption of CO2. Moreover, the adsorption capacity and pore size did not show a certain regularity on other silicates. According to the FTIR, silicate materials contained hydroxyl peaks, so this may be due to the hydrogen bond formed by the combination of rich hydroxyl groups on the silicate surface of different metals with CO2, which affected the adsorption performance.
According to TG-DSC results of MgSiO3, MnSiO3, CuSiO3, and ZrSiO4 shown in Fig. S8, all of these compounds had remarkable
thermal stability. Three stages of MgSiO3 weight loss were observed (Fig. S8a), The weight was lost at 98 °C, corresponding to loss of physically adsorbed water. In the stage of 400–750 °C, the weight was lost for 11%, which linked to the dehydroxylation of residual Mg(OH)2 [54] and crystal water. Because the solution system is alkaline, Mg2+ will produce a small amount of Mg(OH)2 precipitation in alkaline environment. Furthermore, DSC results showed a sharp peak due to the transformation to crystalline of MgSiO3 at 824 °C [55]. In MnSiO3, the loss of physically adsorbed water was found at 105 °C (Fig. S8b). The continuous weight loss at 200–600 °C was due to its dehydroxylation [56]. Between 600 °C and 800 °C, the weight loss was slow, and TG curve was almost level off. As shown in Fig. S8(c) of CuSiO3, an endothermic peak appeared at 110 °C with a weight loss of 2%, corresponding to the loss of physically adsorbed water. The weight loss at 200–400 °C should be attributed to the removal of water in CuO-SiO2H2O system at 200–400 °C. A fast mass loss was also found at 604 °C, which was due to the release of CO2 and water from by-product [57]. As shown in Fig. S8(d), the mass loss of ZrSiO4 was about 4 wt% below 120 °C was due to the removal of physically adsorbed water. The weight loss within 120–400 °C was attributed to the removal of crystal water. The loss between 400 °C and 800 °C was ascribed to the dehydration of hydroxyl groups. Furthermore, there was a step weight loss and an obvious exothermic peak at 894 °C due to crystallization peak of ZrSiO4 [58].
As shown in Fig. 7 of SEM images of products, their rough surface morphology was rough and consisted of generous in ordinance nanoparticles (Fig. 7(a)–(d)). TEM images of SBNMs (Fig. 8) indicated that MgSiO3 had a layered structure (Fig. 8(a)) [50] with a lot of aggregations were comprised of nanoparticles (Fig. 8(b)–(d)), which were in consistent with SEM images.

sections.heading: 3.5. CO2 adsorption
sections.text: The CO2 adsorption isotherm curves at 25 °C were presented in Fig. 9, showing that the adsorption amount of CO2 was increased with the increase of pressure. With the relative atomic mass of Mn, Cu and Zr was gradually increased in MnSiO3, CuSiO3 and ZrSiO4, the CO2 adsorption amounts of MnSiO3, CuSiO3 and ZnSiO4 were decreased correspondingly (17.93, 10.59 and 7.82 cm3/g). The CO2 adsorption amount of MgSiO3 with the alkaline-earth Mg element was 14.97 cm3/ g. Meanwhile, the other CO2 adsorbents were reported in Table 7. As we can see, the amount of CO2 adsorbed by the SBNMs was lower than that of the surface modified adsorbents [61,70] and MOFs [68,69]. However, the CO2 adsorption amount on the SBNMs were similar with some adsorbents without modification, such as Unmodified X zeolite [63], MCM-41 [66]. And the silicon source of synthetic SBNMs came from waste coal gangue, which reduced the cost of materials synthesis and realized the green utilization of coal gangue.

sections.heading: 3.6. Adsorption isotherms
sections.text:
Fig. 10 showed the adsorption of CO2 on SBNMs at different temperatures (25 °C, 40 °C, 55 °C, and 70 °C). In order to further understand the interaction between gas molecules and the surface of adsorbent at various temperatures, two different models of Freundlich and Langmuir were chosen. The formula was described as follows [71,72]:

where K is the Freundlich constant that relates to the adsorption capacity, and n is the index that stands for adsorption strength; and q (cm3/g) and p (bar) are the amount of adsorption of CO2 and the pressure under different adsorption capacity, where qm (cm3/g) represents the maximum adsorption capacity, and b is the affinity constant.
The adsorption isotherms of Freundlich and Langmuir models were shown in Fig. 11 and Fig. S9. The Langmuir and Freundlich models
fitting parameters and correlation coefficients (R2) were collected in Table 8. Results clearly indicated that the Freundlich model was better fitted to the experimental data, which was also affirmed by the value of the regression coefficient R2 [73], so the Freudlich model was a better fit than the Langmuir model. The fitting results indicated that CO2 was adsorbed on the SBNMs with a multi-layer manner and the surface of
the adsorbent is not uniform [74,75].

The specific thermodynamic parameters for the adsorption of CO2 on the SNBMs were listed in Tables S1–S4. As shown in Fig. 10, the CO2 adsorption amounts progressively decreased as the temperature increased, which suggested that the adsorption of CO2 on SBNMs is a typical physical adsorption, so the binding force of CO2 molecules to the surface of the adsorbents is van der Waals force. From Fig. 12(b) and (c), the equivalent heat of adsorption was decreased with the increase of q value, while the equivalent heat of adsorption was increased with the increase of q value (Fig. 12a), which was mainly due to the interaction force between the adsorbed molecules. With the increase of q value, the interaction force
among the adsorbed molecules in the adsorption phase was gradually enhanced, leading to the increase of Qst value. As shown in Fig. 12(d), the adsorption heat was decreased first and then increased with the increase of adsorption amount, which could be consistent with the force between the surface and CO2 [73]. As shown in Tables S1–S4, negative value of ΔHads indicated that the adsorption process was exothermic [75]. The negative value of ΔSads indicated an increase in randomness at the solid/gas interface and the degree of freedom was reduced during the adsorption process [75]. The negative value of ΔGads values suggested that the adsorption process led to a decrease in Gibbs free energy and indicated the adsorption process was spontaneous [80].

sections.heading: 3.8. Recycled study
sections.text: Recycling stability was another major issue, which involved replacement of adsorbents and the cost. The recycling process of CO2 adsorption at 25 °C on the SBNMs were shown in Fig. 13. And the desorption method is heated for 2 h in a vacuum drying oven of 120 °C. In general, CO2 adsorption amount could be kept excellently up to 10 cycles, indicating that MgSiO3, MnSiO3, CuSiO3 and ZnSiO4 were very stable during the adsorption and desorption without significant loss in efficiency.

sections.heading: 3.9. Adsorption selectivity of CO2/N2
sections.text: Since CO2 from the tail gases (75% of nitrogen, 10–15% of CO2 and a small amount of corrosive gases) of fuel engines was often seen as the greenhouse gas, the efficient separation of CO2 from N2 was important to determine the efficiency of CO2 adsorbents SBNMs, which was done at 25 °C and 1 atm. As shown in Fig. 14, the amount of adsorption of N2 on SBNMs were less than 0.45 cm3/g with the CO2/N2 ratio of 39, indicating these SBNMs had a particularly high CO2 selectivity over N2. This was because SBNMs were rich in hydroxyl basic groups and formed hydrogen bonds with CO2, which led to selective adsorption of CO2.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: The CG was used to prepare four SBNMs (MgSiO3, MnSiO3, CuSiO3 and ZnSiO4) with low cost, excellent CO2 adsorption and desorption cycling stability, and high CO2 selectivity over N2. The highest SiO32− extraction ratio from the CCG was up to 77.69% under the optimum conditions as follows: calcination temperature of 1000 °C, NaOH concentration of 150 g/L, m(CCG)/m(NaOH) ratio of 15, reaction temperature of 100 °C, and reaction time of 2 h. All SBNMs were readily prepared from the extracted SiO32− with Mn/Si mole ratio of 1: 1 and pH of 10.00 at 140 °C for 10 h. MgSiO3, MnSiO3, CuSiO3 and ZnSiO4 showed their CO2 adsorption uptake of 14.97, 17.93, 10.59 and 7.82 cm3/g, respectively. Furthermore, the Freundlich model could be used to describe the CO2 adsorption process on all SBNMs. Additionally, thermodynamic parameters of ΔGads, ΔHads and ΔSads showed that the adsorption process was chemically favored, spontaneous and exothermic.

metadata.abstractText: As one of the most important approaches to reduce CO2 emission from various combustion processes, CO2 adsorption capture is facing several many challenges, including high adsorbent cost, high energy cost, and low CO2 selectivity. In this work, four novel silicate-based nanomaterials (SBNMs), including magnesium silicate (MgSiO3), manganese silicate (MnSiO3), copper silicate (CuSiO3) and zirconium silicate (ZrSiO4), were fabricated via hydrothermal method with SiO3 extracted from coal gangue (CG) for the adsorption capture of CO2. Under the optimum conditions, the SiO3 extraction ratio from the CG reached to 77.69%. The extracted SiO3 was used to synthesize SBNMs with high surface area and high thermal stability, which were characterized with Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction, transmission electron microscopy, and nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms technologies. These as-obtained SBNMs exhibited CO2 adsorption capability of (7.82–17.93) cm/g at 25 °C under 1 atm, respectively. The CO2 adsorption data were successfully fitted with Freundlich model, and the adsorption processes were obvious chemically favored, spontaneous and exothermic according to thermodynamic parameters, including Qst, ΔGads, ΔHads and ΔSads. Significantly, all SBNMs showed a excellent cycle performance and strong selectivity toward CO2 over N2. The aim of this work is to provide a new method of utilization of coal gangue waste and a low-cost, and highly selective CO2 adsorbents.
